abstract: The production design for "Hugo" included a bookstore set filled with 40,000 books, some of them actually fiberglass painted to look like tomes.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences released its shortlist of contenders for the visual effects Oscar yesterday, and the Bagger's readers already have quibbles with the selection. Why didn't "The Adventures of Tintin," "Super 8" and "Green Lantern" (yes, the lone fan has spoken up) make the cut? The 10 films that did make it through include "Hugo," which may well also be a contender in another visual category, best art direction. The Bagger's colleague, Mekado Murphy, takes a closer look at the production design of that film, which included a bookstore set with 40,000 books, or, shall we say, booklike objects. Some of the "books" are actually fiberglass creations painted to look like tomes. "Since the books are so heavy, when you have to move them for the camera, you lose too much time," explained the production designer, Dante Ferretti. Read more »
